intro: Styphelia opponens, commonly known as the narrowleaf snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its small, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils in forest understories, often in moist, shaded environments. Its leaves are narrow and evergreen, contributing to its ornamental value in gardens. Styphelia opponens produces white or pale pink blooms in the spring, adding a delicate touch to its natural habitat.
